text:
Hi Viktor,
thank for all the information,

I felt like you jump a bit too early for uvs and texturing, but that maybe depend on where you plan to texture and render.

For a game engine your modelling is on an Ok level, for realist render on any raytracer I believe you won't have enough info/modelling detail.

There's some gotcha's on your currentl model that will not deliver a realistic result at the end.
- all your pavement and roads, are very simplist in terms of model , I would bevel and pay more attention to your phot references
- your close up main objects the chariot , the piano, the wood barrel carrier, all are low poly,
this may cause you issue if you go to close on them
The tram is quite good, just be careful not to go to close.

All the environment are pretty good, just believe you just have too much work in front of you.
Too many scenes, all of them very challenging, but if you keep putting the same effort you will succeeded. 

Let me know how are you planning to render the sequences, game engine or on raytracer.

Texturing needs good model to bounce of and shine ,so be carefull with sharp edges .

Your uving process will also need to be consist of how are you rendering.

Question: what are you doing with your character ? Do you need to animate it ? 

You are doing great,specially as this is all by yourself. 
If we had this project I would get a team of 2 to 3 artist and give them 3 months of full time work to achieve photo real.

Let me know your thoughts ,

Thank you , keep it up

Johnny
Thanks Johnny, I'll look through this in an hour and make some notes, then get back to you with any question I'll have

So I read through your feedback. It has given me a lot to think about, thank you. I will be using Arnold ray tracing to render my sequences. My character will not be moving. It's an ongoing issue with me because I keep contemplating if I should include him in my scenes or just leave him for my showreel as a separate asset. I can see how my scenes look too simple and will work towards adding more detail to them.

Just wondering. When you look at showreel sent to you. What specific things do you look for in them? 

I'm just worried that because I'm coming from a animation background, I lack the experience in the vfx field.

It’s all good , when applying for environment I will be looking for a person with strong generalist approach.  Your animation background is a plus , if you can still deliver great looking visual .
By orders of preference:
• good composition , conveying mood and feeling of the environment represented 
• After that I will look how good your modelling is 
• How good is your attention to detail and realism 
• Textures and shaders 
• Lighting 
• Composite 
• You would never judge camera movement or animation of characters on a environment reel 

On a interview I would ask how clever was your workflows .
Doing a hand painted for an hero asset is great , but  hand painted every single wood plank is a waste of your time ,
Workflows of tileable textures or smart material in painter are a great way to have realist result without every asset being a hero level 

Substance designer , painter , Mari , Houdini , speedtree would be some of the software that I could recommend now 

Rendering in Arnold that interior will be hard , you will need to do some tricks , exterior will be fine , but with flat models it’s tricky to convey realism ,
Displacement is very heavy and ram consuming 

Do you know .tx that Arnold uses ? 
That’s a good shortcut 

Be careful with too many textures but also low resolution on close up ,

Later will be able to talk to you about DMP but for now let’s get all the rest in

Let me know what you are planning to work 1st, I will be able to help you whatever part you are working on .
Also important is for you to finish you degree , that it’s also good for you resume ! 
So we should never comprise your final delivery !

Amazing, thank you! Think my first step now is to figure our my final camera shots and movements and work on the ground detail. 

We use zbrush and photoshop to texture at my uni. Do you recommend I learn substance painter in my free time? I looked into it this summer and felt like zbrush has a pretty similar approach so thought it would be best if I stuck to the programme my lecturers knew more about.

In zbrush you can paint , but only using poly paint , that means always haven’t to subdivide everything ,
Painter its not just a painting tool , but also a shading tool , I would recommend you have it as your plan b and secret weapon .
Stick with zbrush but give a few assets a spin in painter
